Scientific Forecaster Discussion

Return to Local Conditions & Forecast

Without Abbreviations
With Abbreviations

Area forecast discussion 
National Weather Service Twin Cities/Chanhassen Minnesota 
636 PM CST Thu Nov 24 2016 

Update... 
issued at 606 PM CST Thu Nov 24 2016 

Updated to include 00z aviation discussion below. 

&& 

Short term...(this evening through friday) 
issued at 410 PM CST Thu Nov 24 2016 

The main weather maker for the short term is the shortwave trough 
currently seen on water vapor imagery working into west central 
and southwest Minnesota. Differential positive vorticity advection and some weak warm 
advection are leading to quite a few returns on radar, but only 
spotty light snow observations can be found. This area of forcing 
and precipitation will slide east through the evening, producing 
some light mixed precipitation initially, and then some light 
snow, mainly over the southern portion of the area. Amounts will 
be minimal. Otherwise, we look to remain socked in with low clouds 
and some fog through much of the day tomorrow, before we begin to 
see a clearing trend from west to east as the surface ridge axis 
starts to shift east of the area and we see a bit more in the way 
of southwesterly flow. 

Long term...(friday night through thursday) 
issued at 410 PM CST Thu Nov 24 2016 

Main concern for the long term is the deep system coming up Sunday 
and how long it will linger across the area. What's not in 
question is p-type area wide with this system with a path going 
into the Dakotas firmly planting the mpx County Warning Area in a warm sector for 
the bulk of the precip Sunday night into Monday, meaning this will 
be a primarily rain event to end November. 

Friday night through Sunday morning will be quiet weather wise and 
will likely offer US our only chances at glimpsing clearish skies 
over the next week. By Saturday, h85 temps will rise to around 
+8c. This will allow for highs to warm into the 40s, especially 
on Saturday when we'll have a chance at seeing the sun, but the 
clear skies overnight will allow for a bit of a diurnal range to 
the temperatures, with lows falling back into the 20s. 

For the system that will begin impacting the region on Sunday, we 
have actually seen an increase in model spread with the strength, 
timing, and movement of the system. With the 24.12 model runs, 
everything slowed down. The reason for this is that as this wave 
comes out of The Rockies on Sunday, there is another closed h5 low 
over eastern Canada that is checking everything up back this 
direction. The slowest model continues to be the European model (ecmwf) as it 
actually develops a Rex block over central Canada, with the h5 low 
forecast to sit and spin over Minnesota from Monday through Thursday. 

No matter how many days it takes for the h5 low to clear the area, 
the bulk of the precipitation is still expected to come up Sunday 
evening in a strong surge of waa, Theta-E, and pws. In fact, the 
GFS has pwats increasing to near 0.9", which is above the 
climatological record for the end of November. Although it will 
rain Sunday evening into Monday morning, our 6 hourly pops were 
actually decreased into the mainly likely range and this is thanks 
to about a 6-12 hour timing difference between GFS (faster) and 
Canadian/European model (ecmwf) (slower). Beside a slight decrease in pop values, 
we also slowed down how quickly pops move north. In addition, as 
this initial surge moves north, h85-h5 differential Theta-E 
decreases to near zero. Indicative of a weakly stable environment, 
so if isentropic lift is vigorous enough, we may be able to scare 
a rumble or two of thunder out of this. Kept thunder mention out 
of the grids for now though due to timing differences in the 
models, with the GFS having the thunder threat Sunday night while 
the European model (ecmwf) would have it about 12 hours later. The other thing that 
could change a bit depending on the speed of this system are the 
highs for Monday. If we get a slower speed like the Canadian and 
ECMWF, we could see a good deal of highs into the low 50s south of 
I-94, so expect the potential for some movement with that aspect 
of the forecast as well on Monday. 

For the rest of the week, we will be in a moist cyclonic flow 
regime through at least Wednesday, which means gray skies and 
little diurnal trend in temepratures. Basically, for Tuesday 
through Thursday, we will see highs each day a couple of degrees 
cooler than the previous day. We have chance pops persisting 
through this period as well and that's thanks to the European model (ecmwf) 
solution, which has light qpf continuing into Thursday as the 
upper low slowly trudges across the upper MS River Valley. 

&& 

Aviation...(for the 00z tafs through 00z Friday evening) 
issued at 606 PM CST Thu Nov 24 2016 

A weak shortwave trough aloft will continue pushing through the 
region this evening into the early morning hours. Much of the 
precipitation is changing over to -sn and will continue as such 
through this evening. In addition, with plenty of low level 
moisture in place, fog will develop over much of the area and will 
persist through the overnight hours. This combination will make 
IFR or worse conditions likely overnight and potentially beyond 
daybreak. Improvement will be slow to develop during the day 
tomorrow but the expectation is that VFR conditions will be 
realized before the end of the day tomorrow. 

Kmsp...precipitation at initialization is -rasn which will 
gradually change over to -sn. In addition, ceilings which will 
start out above 1700ft will drop to below that level in the first 
couple hours of the 25/00z taf then likely remain below 1700ft 
overnight through much of the day tomorrow. Temperatures will 
remain around 32 deg f so am not expecting any accumulation but 
the falling -sn will impact visibilities. 

/Outlook for kmsp/ 
Sat...VFR. Southeast wind 5-10 kt. 
Sun...mainly VFR. MVFR developing late with -ra. Southeast wind 10-20 
kt. 
Mon...MVFR early with -ra. SW wind 10-20 kt. 

&& 

Mpx watches/warnings/advisories... 
WI...none. 
Minnesota...none. 
&& 

$$ 

Update...jpc 
short term... 
long term...mpg 
aviation...jpc

National Weather Service Glossary of Abbreviations
